BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Avalanches are possible in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place. Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in some places. The snowpack remains unstable above approximately 2300 m. Artificially triggered avalanches confirm this situation.
Some large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible. This applies in case of releases originating from steep, high-altitude starting zones that still retain some snow.
Several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday.
As a consequence of warming during the day dry and moist avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain.
During the day: Moderate northwesterly wind. The fresh wind slabs will form in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In addition the wind slabs of Sunday are capable of being triggered in some locations.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 70 to 160 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 1800 m.
The southeasterly wind has transported some snow. Large wind slabs formed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. New snow is lying on soft layers.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. A little new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of the weekend represent the main danger. At intermediate and high altitudes the situation is very dangerous.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 80 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m. The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released easily or naturally above approximately 1900 m.
Already many large and, in isolated cases, very large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease. Some large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are, however, further not ruled out. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the strong easterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend. New snow is lying on soft layers. This snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. In some places new snow is lying on a moist old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.
Tuesday: Some new snow to above approximately 900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of the weekend represent the main danger. At intermediate and high altitudes the situation is very dangerous.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m.

The large quantity of fresh snow and the large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and in all altitude zones.
Large avalanches are possible in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint. Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of heavy snowfall and the moderate to strong wind, the snowpack could not consolidate during the last few days. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong southerly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.
Tuesday: Some new snow to above approximately 900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of the weekend represent the main danger. At intermediate and high altitudes the situation is very dangerous.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m. The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released easily or naturally above approximately 1900 m.
Large and, in isolated cases, very large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease. Some large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are, however, further not ruled out. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong easterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend. New snow is lying on soft layers. This snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. In some places new snow is lying on a moist old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs: Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in some places. Artificially triggered avalanches confirm this situation. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches, including large ones.
During the day: Moderate northwesterly wind. The fresh wind slabs will form in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In addition the wind slabs of Sunday are capable of being triggered in some locations.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain. As a consequence of warming during the day dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m.
The southeasterly wind has transported some snow.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. Some new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days. As a consequence of the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line.
The wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The moderate wind has transported the old snow.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and has a loosely bonded surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs: Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in some places. Artificially triggered avalanches confirm this situation. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches, including large ones.
During the day: Moderate northwesterly wind. The fresh wind slabs will form in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In addition the wind slabs of Sunday are capable of being triggered in some locations.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m.
The southeasterly wind has transported some snow. Sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. The avalanche danger will increase during the day. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise. Avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep west and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also on very steep north facing slopes above approximately 2100 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

As a consequence of the new snow loose snow avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones.
In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday above approximately 1500 m. Over a wide area up to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1200 m.

As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs have increased in size. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. They are in some cases prone to triggering. This applies above the tree line.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Wednesday. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size. Numerous small and medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs represent the main danger.
Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches are the main danger. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
An appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep east, north and west facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be wet all the way through below approximately 2200 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.

Afternoon: Above approximately 1500 m snow will fall over a wide area.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies above approximately 2600 m. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the new snow. Numerous small and medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be barely evident. The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning. Already in the early morning, individual, then as a consequence of the rain more, and in some cases even medium-sized, wet and gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Moist and wet avalanches and ground avalanches are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time, in particular on steep slopes below approximately 1800 m.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, above approximately 2000 m.
Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular in the north a lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The snowpack remains generally moist.
In addition the wind slabs of yesterday in particular adjacent to ridgelines and at high altitudes are prone to triggering in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Until the temperature drops there will be an increase in the danger of moist avalanches within the current danger level. Moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small. In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
The more recent wind slabs are mostly shallow and can only be released by large loads in most cases. Over a wide area 2 to 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall in the evening above approximately 1200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2200 m. The snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of Wednesday is to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. The danger of loose snow avalanches will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist loose snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow is to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before. Above approximately 1800 m and on steep west, north and east facing slopes the avalanche danger is one level higher. Also in gullies and bowls the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is lying on top of a weakly bonded old snowpack above approximately 1900 m. In some cases new snow is lying on a wet old snowpack.
